intro: Tapinanthus hexasepalus, commonly known as the six-lobed dodder, is a parasitic flowering plant that lacks chlorophyll and relies entirely on host plants for nutrients. It belongs to the Orobanchaceae family and is characterized by its thread-like stems that attach to host plants through haustoria. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers that are typically white or yellow in color. It is native to Africa and is often found growing on various host species such as grasses and shrubs. Due to its parasitic nature, it can have negative impacts on the growth and health of its host plants.
